name: Acute Cholecystitis
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Does the pain radiate to your right shoulder or back?" (Boas Sign - Phrenic nerve C3-C5 irritation)
  • "Did this start after a fatty meal?" (CCK release contracts GB against obstruction)
  • "How long has the pain lasted? >6 hours?" (Distinguishes from Biliary Colic)
  • "Have you had fevers, shivers, or rigors?" (Suggests inflammation/infection/cholangitis)
  • "Has your urine become dark or stools pale?" (Suggests CBD obstruction/Mirizzi)
Differential Diagnosis
  • Biliary Colic: Pain <6h, No fever, Normal inflammatory markers.
  • Peptic Ulcer Disease: Burning epigastric pain, hunger pain, NSAID history.
  • Right Lower Lobe Pneumonia: Respiratory symptoms, fever, decreased breath sounds.
  • Acute Pancreatitis: Radiates to back (transfixion), high amylase/lipase.
  • Fitz-Hugh-Curtis Syndrome: Perihepatitis associated with PID/Gonorrhea.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

The primary symptom begins as visceral, diffuse epigastric or periumbilical pain that localizes to the Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ) (somatic pain via parietal peritoneum irritation). The pain is constant, severe, and lasts >6 hours, unlike the waxing/waning of colic. Radiation to the right scapula (Boas' sign) or shoulder tip is common.

Associated Symptoms

Anorexia, nausea, vomiting (bilious), fever, and rigors.
etiology:
Pathophysiology

90-95% calculous: Obstruction of the cystic duct by a gallstone causes distension, venous/lymphatic congestion, ischemia, and secondary bacterial infection. 5-10% acalculous: Associated with critical illness, burns, or sepsis (stasis/ischemia).

Microbiology

E. coli (most common), Klebsiella, Enterococcus, Bacteroides.

Risk Factors (5 F's)

Fat, Female, Forty, Fertile, Fair. Also hemolytic anemia (pigment stones) and rapid weight loss.
exam:
General

Tachycardia, Pyrexia (>38°C). Patient lies still to avoid peritoneal irritation. Shallow breathing (splinting).

Abdomen

Localized RUQ tenderness and guarding. Palpable gallbladder mass may be present (if omentum walls it off).

Specific Signs

Murphy's Sign: Inspiratory arrest on deep palpation of RUQ (positive only if negative on left).
Boas' Sign: Hyperaesthesia below the right scapula (T9-T11).
inv:
Bedside

Urine Dip (Exclude renal colic/UTI/DKA). ECG (Rule out inferior MI).

Labs

FBC (Leukocytosis with left shift), CRP (High), LFTs (Mild alkaline phosphatase rise; significant bilirubin suggests CBD stone/Mirizzi), Amylase (Exclude pancreatitis).

Imaging

USG Abdomen (Gold Standard): Thickened GB wall >3mm, pericholecystic fluid, presence of stones/sludge, positive sonographic Murphy's sign, distended gallbladder. HIDA Scan: If USG equivocal (non-filling of GB).
mgmt:
Resuscitation

Keep NBM, IV Fluids (crystalloids), Analgesia (NSAIDs/Opioids), Antiemetics.

Medical

IV Antibiotics (e.g., Cefuroxime + Metronidazole or Piperacillin-Tazobactam).

Surgical

Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy: Early (<72h of onset) or within 1 week is preferred over delayed interval surgery.

Interventional

Percutaneous Cholecystostomy (drainage) for high-risk surgical candidates (Tokyo Grade III).
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Empyema of Gallbladder: Pus-filled GB; high fever, sepsis, risk of perforation.
  • Gangrenous Cholecystitis: Ischemia leading to perforation and generalized peritonitis.
  • Emphysematous Cholecystitis: Gas-forming organisms (Clostridium); high mortality, common in diabetics.
  • Cholecystoenteric Fistula: Adhesion to duodenum → Gallstone Ileus.
Treatment Related
  • Bile Duct Injury (0.3%).
  • Bile Leak (Biloma).
  • Retained Common Bile Duct Stone.
  • Post-cholecystectomy Syndrome.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Tokyo Guidelines (2018)
Grade I (Mild): Healthy patient → Lap Chole.
Grade II (Mod): WBC >18, mass, duration >72h → Antibiotics/Drain then Surgery.
Grade III (Severe): Organ failure → Percutaneous Drainage.
ðŸ’Ž Mirizzi Syndrome
A stone impacted in the cystic duct or Hartmann's pouch compresses the Common Hepatic Duct, causing obstructive jaundice.

name: Gallstones (Biliary Colic)
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Does the pain come and go, or is it constant?" (Colic vs Inflammatory)
  • "Does it go away completely between attacks?"
  • "Is your urine dark or eyes yellow?" (Rule out Choledocholithiasis)
  • "Did this happen after eating greasy/fatty food?" (Post-prandial)
  • "Any fever or shivers?" (Rule out Cholecystitis)
Differential Diagnosis
  • Acute Cholecystitis: Fever, constant pain >6h, +Murphy's.
  • Gastritis/GERD: Burning pain, relieved by antacids.
  • Acute Pancreatitis: Radiates to back, severe, vomiting.
  • Peptic Ulcer Disease: Hunger pain, periodicity.
  • Renal Colic: Loin to groin radiation, hematuria.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Intermittent, severe RUQ or epigastric pain, often radiating to the back or right shoulder. Typically occurs post-prandially (especially fatty meals) and lasts <6 hours (usually 1-4 hours). Pain resolves completely between episodes. Nausea and vomiting are common.

Associated Symptoms

No fever, no systemic inflammatory response.
etiology:
Pathophysiology

Transient obstruction of the cystic duct by a stone during gallbladder contraction.

Stone Types

Cholesterol (Mixed): 80%, associated with obesity, diet.
Pigment (Black): Hemolysis, cirrhosis.
Pigment (Brown): Biliary stasis, infection.

Risk Factors

5 F's (Fat, Female, Forty, Fertile, Fair), Rapid weight loss, Crohn's disease (terminal ileum resection disrupts bile salt resorption).
exam:
General

Patient is afebrile and comfortable between attacks. During attack, patient is restless (colic).

Abdomen

Soft, non-tender (or mild voluntary guarding) between attacks. Negative Murphy's sign. No jaundice (unless complicated).
inv:
Bedside

Urine Dip (Normal).

Labs

WBC, CRP, and LFTs should be normal. Elevated ALP/GGT suggests stone passage or CBD stone.

Imaging

USG Abdomen: Mobile echogenic foci with posterior acoustic shadowing. Gallbladder wall is thin (<3mm) with no pericholecystic fluid.
mgmt:
Conservative

Analgesia (NSAIDs like Diclofenac are superior to opioids for colic), Antispasmodics (Hyoscine), Low-fat diet.

Surgical

Elective Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy to prevent complications (cholecystitis, pancreatitis).

Medical

Ursodeoxycholic acid (rarely used, high recurrence).
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Acute Cholecystitis.
  • Choledocholithiasis (Obstructive Jaundice/Cholangitis).
  • Gallstone Pancreatitis (Small stones).
  • Gallstone Ileus (Fistula to duodenum).
  • Mucocele of Gallbladder (Hydrops).
Treatment Related
  • Bile Duct Injury (0.3%).
  • Bleeding (Cystic artery).
  • Wound Infection.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Saint's Triad
The coexistence of Gallstones + Diverticulosis + Hiatus Hernia.
ðŸ’Ž Mercedes Benz Sign
Radiolucent nitrogen gas fissures within a gallstone seen on X-ray/CT.

name: Acute Pancreatitis
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Does the pain go straight through to your back?" (Transfixion)
  • "Does sitting forward relieve the pain?" (Relaxes retroperitoneum)
  • "Do you drink alcohol? How much?"
  • "Do you have a history of gallstones?"
  • "Any recent ERCP, trauma, or new medications?"
Differential Diagnosis
  • Perforated PUD: Air under diaphragm on CXR, board-like rigidity.
  • Acute Cholecystitis: RUQ pain, Murphy's +, no back radiation.
  • Inferior MI: Epigastric pain, ECG changes.
  • Ruptured AAA: Hemodynamic collapse, pulsatile mass, known aneurysm.
  • Mesenteric Ischemia: Pain out of proportion to exam findings, metabolic acidosis.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Sudden onset of severe, constant epigastric pain radiating through to the back (50% of cases). The pain is "boring" in nature. Vomiting is profuse and does not relieve the pain.

Etiology (GET SMASHED)

Gallstones (50%), Ethanol (30%), Trauma, Steroids, Mumps/Malignancy, Autoimmune (IgG4), Scorpion venom, Hypercalcemia/Hyperlipidemia, ERCP, Drugs (Azathioprine, Thiazides).
etiology:
Pathophysiology

Premature intracellular activation of trypsinogen to trypsin → Autodigestion of pancreatic parenchyma → Release of inflammatory mediators (Cytokines) → Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) and third-space fluid loss.
exam:
General

Tachycardia, Hypotension (Shock), Tachypnea, Dehydration (dry mucous membranes).

Abdomen

Epigastric tenderness, distension (ileus). Reduced bowel sounds.

Specific Signs (Late/Severe)

Cullen's Sign: Periumbilical bruising (retroperitoneal hemorrhage tracking via falciform ligament).
Grey Turner's Sign: Flank bruising.
inv:
Bedside

ABG (Hypoxia, Metabolic Acidosis/Lactate), ECG.

Labs

Serum Amylase: >3x upper limit of normal (Non-specific). Serum Lipase: More specific and stays elevated longer. Calcium (Hypocalcemia indicates severity). CRP (prognostic after 48h).

Imaging

USG: To rule out gallstones. CT Pancreas (Contrast): Indicated after 48-72h to assess for necrosis (non-enhancing areas) and complications. Early CT is not useful for diagnosis unless checking for other causes.
mgmt:
Resuscitation (Crucial)

Aggressive IV Fluids (Hartmann's/Lactated Ringer's) to treat third-space loss. Catheterize to monitor urine output (>0.5ml/kg/hr).

Medical

Analgesia (Opioids), Antiemetics. Nutrition: Early enteral nutrition (NG/NJ tube) reduces bacterial translocation compared to TPN. Antibiotics only if infection is proven.

Specific

ERCP: Urgent (<24h) if cholangitis or severe biliary pancreatitis with obstruction. Cholecystectomy: During same admission for mild biliary pancreatitis.
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Systemic (Early): SIRS, ARDS, AKI, DIC, Hypocalcemia, Hyperglycemia.
  • Local (Late >4 weeks): Pancreatic Pseudocyst (fluid collection), Walled-off Necrosis, Abscess, Pseudoaneurysm (Splenic artery).
  • Chronic: Exocrine insufficiency (steatorrhea), Endocrine failure (Diabetes).
Treatment Related
  • Fluid Overload (Pulmonary edema).
  • Catheter related infections.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Glasgow Imrie Score (PANCREAS)
Measured at 48h. Score ≥ 3 = Severe Pancreatitis.
PaO2 <8kPa, Age >55, Neutrophils >15, Calcium <2, Renal (Urea >16), Enzymes (AST/LDH high), Albumin <32, Sugar >10.
ðŸ’Ž Pancreatic Divisum
Failure of dorsal and ventral buds to fuse; predisposes to pancreatitis due to stenosis of the minor papilla.

name: Ca Head of Pancreas
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Have you noticed painless yellowing of your eyes/skin?"
  • "Is your urine dark and stools pale/floating?" (Obstructive Jaundice)
  • "Is your skin itchy?" (Pruritus from bile salts)
  • "Have you lost weight unintentionally?"
  • "Any new onset diabetes or back pain?"
Differential Diagnosis
  • Choledocholithiasis: Painful jaundice, fluctuation in bilirubin.
  • Cholangiocarcinoma: Jaundice, weight loss, palpable GB (distal).
  • Peri-ampullary Carcinoma: Fluctuating jaundice (sloughing tumor).
  • Chronic Pancreatitis/Benign Stricture.
  • Autoimmune Pancreatitis (IgG4).
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Classic presentation is painless progressive obstructive jaundice. Pruritus (often severe). Significant weight loss and anorexia. New onset diabetes in an elderly patient is a red flag. Back pain suggests retroperitoneal invasion (inoperable).
etiology:
Pathology

Ductal Adenocarcinoma (85%). Originates in the head of pancreas (60%), causing early biliary obstruction.

Risk Factors

Smoking (strongest link), Chronic Pancreatitis, Diabetes, Obesity, Age >60. Genetic: BRCA2, Lynch Syndrome (HNPCC), FAMMM.
exam:
General

Jaundice (sclera/skin), Cachexia, Scratch marks (excoriations).

Abdomen

Palpable non-tender gallbladder (Courvoisier's Sign). Hepatomegaly. Ascites (late sign).

Specific Signs

Courvoisier's Law: In the presence of jaundice, a palpable non-tender gallbladder is unlikely to be due to gallstones (usually malignancy).
Trousseau's Sign: Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (paraneoplastic).
inv:
Labs

LFTs: Cholestatic pattern (High Bilirubin, High ALP/GGT). Tumor Marker: CA 19-9 (Diagnostic and monitoring). Coagulation profile (Prolonged PT/INR due to Vit K malabsorption).

Imaging

CT Pancreas (Pancreatic protocol): "Double duct sign" (dilation of CBD and Pancreatic duct). Assess resectability (SMV/SMA/Portal vein invasion). EUS (Endoscopic Ultrasound): For biopsy (FNA) and local staging.
mgmt:
Curative (15-20%)

Whipple's Procedure (Pancreaticoduodenectomy): Removal of pancreatic head, duodenum, gallbladder, and distal CBD.

Palliative

Obstructive Jaundice: ERCP with metal stenting or PTC. Gastric Outlet Obstruction: Gastrojejunostomy or duodenal stent. Pain: Celiac plexus block. Enzymes: Creon (Pancrelipase).

Systemic

Chemotherapy (FOLFIRINOX or Gemcitabine).
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Biliary Obstruction (Cholangitis, Hepatic failure).
  • Duodenal Obstruction (Vomiting).
  • Cachexia/Malnutrition.
  • Venous Thromboembolism.
Treatment Related
  • Post-Whipple: Pancreatic Fistula (leakage of amylase rich fluid).
  • Delayed Gastric Emptying.
  • Post-pancreatectomy Hemorrhage.
  • Diabetes Mellitus (Brittle).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Double Duct Sign
Simultaneous dilation of the Common Bile Duct and Pancreatic Duct seen on CT/MRCP; highly suggestive of pancreatic head malignancy.
ðŸ’Ž Exceptions to Courvoisier's
1. Double pathology (stones + cancer).
2. Oriental cholangiohepatitis.
3. Gallbladder mucocoele.
4. Cystic duct obstruction.

name: Hepatocellular Carcinoma
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Do you have a history of Hepatitis B or C?"
  • "How much alcohol do you drink?"
  • "Have you noticed sudden swelling of your belly?" (Decompensation)
  • "Have you lost weight?"
  • "Family history of liver cancer?"
Differential Diagnosis
  • Liver Metastasis: 20x more common than primary HCC.
  • Cirrhosis with Regenerative Nodule.
  • Hemangioma: Benign, peripheral enhancement.
  • Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (FNH): Central scar.
  • Cholangiocarcinoma: Intrahepatic.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Often asymptomatic surveillance finding. Symptoms include RUQ pain, weight loss, or signs of decompensated cirrhosis (ascites, variceal bleed, encephalopathy).

Risk Factors

Cirrhosis (Alcohol, NASH), Hepatitis B (can cause HCC without cirrhosis), Hepatitis C, Aflatoxin B1 exposure, Hemochromatosis, Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.
etiology:
Pathology

Malignant transformation of hepatocytes. Arises in a background of chronic inflammation and regeneration.

Microscopic

Trabecular pattern, bile production by tumor cells.
exam:
General

Stigmata of Chronic Liver Disease (Jaundice, Spider Naevi, Palmar Erythema, Gynecomastia).

Abdomen

Hepatomegaly (Hard, irregular/craggy edge). Ascites. Arterial Bruit over the liver (due to high vascularity).
inv:
Labs

AFP (Alpha-fetoprotein): >400 ng/ml is diagnostic in appropriate context.

Imaging

Multiphasic CT/MRI: Hallmark is Arterial Enhancement (wash-in) and Venous Washout (hypodense in portal venous phase).

Biopsy

Generally avoided if imaging is diagnostic (risk of seeding).
mgmt:
Curative

Resection (Hepatectomy): For non-cirrhotic patients or Child-Pugh A.
Liver Transplant: Best for cirrhosis + small tumor (Milan Criteria).

Locoregional

RFA (Radiofrequency Ablation): Lesions <3cm. TACE (Transarterial Chemoembolization): Palliative control.

Systemic

Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors (Sorafenib/Lenvatinib).
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Tumor Rupture (Hemoperitoneum).
  • Portal Vein Thrombosis.
  • Liver Failure.
  • Metastasis (Lung/Bone).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Milan Criteria
Criteria for transplantation: Single lesion <5cm OR up to 3 lesions <3cm each, no vascular invasion/mets.
ðŸ’Ž Child-Pugh Score
Assess liver reserve (Bilirubin, Albumin, INR, Ascites, Encephalopathy).

name: Cholangiocarcinoma
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Are you jaundiced?"
  • "Do you have Ulcerative Colitis?" (PSC link)
  • "History of liver flukes?" (Travel to Asia)
  • "Is your skin itchy?"
  • "Have you lost weight?"
Differential Diagnosis
  • Ca Head of Pancreas: Similar obstructive picture.
  • Choledocholithiasis: Painful, intermittent.
  • Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC): Beaded strictures.
  • IgG4 Cholangiopathy: Steroid responsive.
  • Mirizzi Syndrome.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Painless obstructive jaundice (pale stool, dark urine), pruritus, weight loss.

Risk Factors

Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC) - 10-15% lifetime risk. Choledochal cysts (Caroli's disease). Parasites (Clonorchis sinensis, Opisthorchis viverrini). Hepatolithiasis.
etiology:
Pathology

Adenocarcinoma arising from biliary epithelium (cholangiocytes).

Classification (Bismuth)

Intrahepatic: Mass in liver.
Perihilar (Klatskin): Junction of right/left hepatic ducts.
Distal: Common bile duct.
exam:
General

Deep jaundice, excoriations.

Abdomen

Hepatomegaly. Gallbladder: Palpable only if tumor is distal to cystic duct entry. Non-palpable in Klatskin tumors (collapsed GB).
inv:
Labs

Obstructive LFTs. CA 19-9 (Elevated). CEA. IgG4 (Rule out autoimmune).

Imaging

MRCP (Gold Standard): Defines biliary anatomy/stricture. CT: Staging. ERCP: Brush cytology (low sensitivity).
mgmt:
Surgical

Intrahepatic: Hepatectomy.
Hilar (Klatskin): Extended Hepatectomy + Caudate Lobe + Roux-en-Y Hepaticojejunostomy.
Distal: Whipple's Procedure.

Palliative

Biliary Stenting (ERCP/PTC) to relieve itch/jaundice. Photodynamic Therapy.
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Recurrent Cholangitis (Sepsis).
  • Liver Failure (Biliary Cirrhosis).
  • Portal Vein Invasion.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Klatskin Tumor
Perihilar cholangiocarcinoma occurring at the confluence of right and left hepatic ducts. Features: Jaundice + Collapsed Gallbladder.

name: Gallbladder Carcinoma
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Do you have a long history of gallstones?"
  • "Is the pain constant and accompanied by weight loss?"
  • "Have you noticed any jaundice?" (Late sign)
  • "Do you have a loss of appetite?"
  • "Can you feel a hard lump in your tummy?"
Differential Diagnosis
  • Chronic Cholecystitis.
  • Xanthogranulomatous Cholecystitis: Mimics cancer on imaging.
  • Empyema of Gallbladder.
  • Mirizzi Syndrome.
  • Hepatocellular Carcinoma.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Often asymptomatic/incidental finding post-cholecystectomy (50%). Advanced disease presents with chronic RUQ pain, weight loss, anorexia, and jaundice (if CBD infiltrated).

Risk Factors

Gallstones (esp >3cm), Porcelain Gallbladder (calcified), Salmonella typhi carrier state, Gallbladder polyps >1cm.
etiology:
Pathology

Chronic inflammation → Metaplasia → Dysplasia → Carcinoma. Adenocarcinoma (90%), Squamous cell (10%). Direct invasion into liver segments IV/V is common.
exam:
Signs

Hard, irregular RUQ Mass (tumor + omentum). Jaundice (late/advanced). Virchow's node (metastatic).
inv:
Imaging

USG: Mass replacing GB, loss of interface with liver. CT/MRI: Staging (Liver invasion/Nodes).

Biopsy

Contraindicated if resectable (risk of needle track seeding).
mgmt:
Surgical

T1a (Mucosa): Simple Cholecystectomy is curative.
>T1b (Muscle/Serosa): Radical Cholecystectomy (Cholecystectomy + 2cm liver wedge resection + Regional lymphadenectomy).
Advanced: Palliative chemotherapy (Gemcitabine/Cisplatin).
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Biliary Obstruction.
  • Duodenal Obstruction (Gastric Outlet Obstruction).
  • Liver Metastases.
  • Peritoneal Carcinomatosis.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Porcelain Gallbladder
Calcification of the gallbladder wall due to chronic inflammation. Associated with increased risk of malignancy (formerly thought 25%, now ~5%), but prophylactic cholecystectomy is still often recommended.

name: Upper GI Bleeding
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Is the vomit bright red or coffee grounds?" (Active vs Old)
  • "Is the stool black/tarry and foul smelling?" (Melaena - digested blood)
  • "Do you have liver disease or drink alcohol heavily?" (Varices)
  • "Are you on blood thinners or NSAIDs?"
  • "Do you feel dizzy when standing up?" (Postural hypotension - significant loss)
Differential Diagnosis
  • Peptic Ulcer Disease (PUD): 50% of cases (H. pylori/NSAIDs).
  • Esophageal Varices: Stigmata of chronic liver disease.
  • Mallory-Weiss Tear: History of forceful retching/vomiting.
  • Gastric/Esophageal Cancer: Weight loss, dysphagia, cachexia.
  • Dieulafoy's Lesion: Aberrant large submucosal artery.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Hematemesis (vomiting blood) or Melaena (black tarry stool). Hematochezia (fresh PR bleed) can occur in massive UGIB with rapid transit. Syncope or pre-syncope indicates hemodynamic instability.

Risk Stratification

History of liver disease, previous bleeds, comorbidities (renal/cardiac).
etiology:
Pathophysiology

Bleeding originating proximal to the Ligament of Treitz. Melaena requires ~50-100ml of blood and 14h transit time; bacteria degrade hemoglobin to hematin (black).

Causes

PUD, Gastroduodenal erosions, Varices, Mallory-Weiss, Malignancy, Angiodysplasia.
exam:
General

Signs of shock (pallor, tachycardia, hypotension, cool peripheries). Stigmata of Chronic Liver Disease: Jaundice, spider naevi, palmar erythema, ascites, caput medusae (suggests Varices).

Abdomen

Epigastric tenderness.

Rectal Exam (DRE)

Mandatory. Confirm melaena (tarry, sticky, distinct smell).
inv:
Bedside

ECG, VBG (Lactate, Hb).

Labs

FBC (Hb may be normal initially due to hemoconcentration), Coagulation (INR), U/E (Isolated rise in Urea due to protein meal absorption from blood), LFTs, Crossmatch (4-6 units).

Procedures

OGDS (Esophagogastroduodenoscopy): Diagnostic and therapeutic. Should be performed within 24h of admission (post-resuscitation).
mgmt:
Resuscitation (ABC)

Protect airway (risk of aspiration). 2 Large bore IV cannulas (14/16G). IV Fluids (Crystalloids) / Blood Transfusion (if Hb <70 or unstable). Correct coagulopathy (FFP/Platelets/Vitamin K).

Medical

Non-Variceal: High dose IV PPI (80mg bolus + 8mg/hr infusion) after endoscopy. Tranexamic acid (evidence mixed).
Variceal: Terlipressin/Octreotide (splanchnic vasoconstrictor) + Prophylactic Antibiotics usually before scope.

Endoscopic

PUD: Dual therapy (Adrenaline injection + Clip/Diathermy). Varices: Band Ligation (EVL) or Sclerotherapy. Sengstaken-Blakemore Tube: Temporary tamponade for uncontrollable variceal bleed.
complications:
Complications
  • Hypovolemic Shock / Cardiac Arrest.
  • Aspiration Pneumonia.
  • Re-bleeding (Highest risk in first 72h).
  • Hepatic Encephalopathy (Blood acts as protein meal).
  • AKI (Hypoperfusion).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Glasgow-Blatchford Score (GBS)
Used pre-endoscopy to stratify risk. Score 0 = Low risk (outpatient). Uses: Urea, Hb, Systolic BP, Pulse, Melena, Syncope, Hepatic disease, Cardiac failure.
ðŸ’Ž Rockall Score
Used post-endoscopy to predict mortality. Includes Age, Shock, Comorbidities, Diagnosis, and Stigmata of recent hemorrhage.
ðŸ’Ž Forrest Classification
Endoscopic grading of ulcers:
Ia (Spurting) / Ib (Oozing) → High Risk.
IIa (Vessel) / IIb (Clot) → Intermediate.
IIc (Spot) / III (Clean base) → Low Risk.

name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "What is the relationship of pain to food?"
  • "Does the pain wake you up at night?"
  • "Have you been taking painkillers (NSAIDs) or steroids?"
  • "Have you lost or gained weight?"
  • "Have you had black sticky stools?"
Differential Diagnosis
  • Non-Ulcer Dyspepsia (Functional).
  • Gastric Cancer: Biopsy required to distinguish from GU.
  • Gallstones: RUQ pain.
  • Chronic Pancreatitis.
  • GERD: Heartburn/Regurgitation dominant.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Epigastric burning pain.
Duodenal Ulcer (DU): Pain when hungry (pre-prandial), relieved by food/milk. Night pain (acid secretion). Weight gain (eating soothes).
Gastric Ulcer (GU): Pain worsened by food. Weight loss (fear of eating).
etiology:
Causes

H. pylori: 90% of DU, 70% of GU.
NSAIDs: Inhibit COX-1 prostaglandins (mucosal protection).
Smoking: Impairs healing.
Stress Ulcers: Curling's (Burns), Cushing's (Head injury).
exam:
Signs

Often normal. Epigastric tenderness (Point sign). Anemia signs.
inv:
Diagnosis

OGDS: Visualization and biopsy (essential for GU to rule out cancer).
H. pylori Testing: Urease Breath Test (UBT), Stool Antigen, CLO test (during scope). Serology (IgG) indicates exposure, not active infection.
mgmt:
Medical

Eradication Therapy: Triple Therapy (PPI + Clarithromycin + Amoxicillin/Metronidazole) for 7-14 days.
Acid Suppression: PPI (Omeprazole) or H2-blocker.
Lifestyle: Stop NSAIDs, Smoking cessation.
complications:
Complications
  • Perforation: Peritonitis.
  • Bleeding: Hematemesis/Melaena.
  • Gastric Outlet Obstruction: Pyloric stenosis due to scarring (Project vomiting, succussion splash).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome
Gastrinoma (usually pancreas/duodenum) causing massive acid hypersecretion and multiple refractory ulcers. Associated with MEN1.

name: Perforated Peptic Ulcer
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Did the pain come on suddenly (like a thunderclap)?"
  • "Can you tell me the exact time the pain started?" (Precision suggests perforation)
  • "Do you have a history of ulcers or indigestion?"
  • "Do you have pain in your shoulder tip?" (Kehr's sign - subdiaphragmatic irritation)
  • "Have you been taking NSAIDs or steroids?"
Differential Diagnosis
  • Acute Pancreatitis: High amylase, no free air.
  • Ruptured AAA: Pulsatile mass, shock, back pain.
  • Myocardial Infarction: Epigastric pain, ECG changes.
  • Acute Appendicitis: Valentino's syndrome (fluid tracking to RIF).
  • Mesenteric Ischemia: Acidosis, older patient with AF.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Sudden onset of severe, generalized abdominal pain. Patients often recall the exact moment of onset. Pain is constant and worsened by any movement.

Triad

1. Sudden onset pain. 2. Tachycardia. 3. Abdominal Rigidity.
etiology:
Pathophysiology

Full-thickness destruction of the gastric/duodenal wall → Spillage of acid/bile → Chemical Peritonitis (initial chemical burn) → Bacterial Peritonitis (after 12-24h) → Sepsis.

Causes

PUD (H. pylori, NSAIDs), Gastric Cancer, Trauma.
exam:
General

Patient lies perfectly still. Shallow breathing. Signs of shock (late).

Abdomen

Generalized tenderness. "Board-like" Rigidity (involuntary guarding). Absent bowel sounds (paralytic ileus). Loss of liver dullness on percussion (due to free gas replacing liver).
inv:
Bedside

ABG (Metabolic acidosis, elevated Lactate).

Labs

WBC (Leukocytosis), CRP (High), Amylase (Mild elevation due to absorption from peritoneum, but not as high as pancreatitis).

Imaging

Erect Chest X-Ray (CXR): Free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum) seen in 75% of cases. CT Abdomen: Most sensitive. Shows free air, fluid, and leak site.
mgmt:
Resuscitation

Aggressive IV fluids (crystalloids), NBM, Nasogastric tube (decompression), Urinary catheter.

Medical

Broad-spectrum IV Antibiotics (e.g., Cefuroxime + Metronidazole), IV PPI, Analgesia.

Surgical

Emergency Laparotomy/Laparoscopy: Peritoneal washout. Graham Patch Repair: Closing the perforation using a tongue of omentum sutured over the defect. Biopsy if gastric ulcer (rule out malignancy).
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Septic Shock (Multi-organ failure).
  • Intra-abdominal Abscess (Subphrenic/Pelvic).
  • Enterocutaneous Fistula.
  • Wound Dehiscence.
Treatment Related
  • Leak from repair.
  • Respiratory complications (Pneumonia/Atelectasis due to pain).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Conservative Management?
The "Taylor Method" (NG suction, IV fluids, Abx) can be considered in very selected cases where the perforation has sealed (verified by gastrografin study) and the patient is stable, but surgery is standard.

name: Esophageal & Gastric Ca
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Do you have difficulty swallowing? Solids first then liquids?" (Progressive Dysphagia)
  • "Have you lost weight?"
  • "Do you have a history of heartburn/reflux?" (Adeno risk)
  • "Do you vomit undigested food?"
  • "Is swallowing painful?" (Odynophagia)
Differential Diagnosis
  • Achalasia: Dysphagia to solids and liquids simultaneously.
  • Benign Peptic Stricture.
  • Pharyngeal Pouch (Zenker's): Halitosis, regurgitation.
  • Esophageal Web/Ring (Plummer-Vinson).
  • Stroke/Bulbar Palsy.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Esophageal: Progressive dysphagia (sticking of food), weight loss, regurgitation, hoarseness (RLN invasion).
Gastric: Vague epigastric pain (mimics ulcer), early satiety, weight loss, vomiting (GOO), Virchow's node.
etiology:
Esophageal Types

Squamous Cell (Upper/Mid): Smoking, Alcohol, Hot drinks, Achalasia.
Adenocarcinoma (Lower): GERD, Barrett's Esophagus, Obesity.

Gastric Types

Intestinal: H. pylori, diet (nitrosamines), metaplasia.
Diffuse (Linitis Plastica): Signet ring cells, E-cadherin mutation, genetic.
exam:
Signs

Cachexia, dehydration. Palpable epigastric mass (Gastric). Hepatomegaly.
Metastatic Signs: Virchow's Node (Left supraclavicular), Sister Mary Joseph Nodule (Umbilicus), Krukenberg tumor (Ovary), Blumer's Shelf (Rectal shelf).
inv:
Diagnosis

OGDS + Biopsy: Gold standard.

Staging

CT TAP: Distant mets. EUS: T-stage (depth) and N-stage. PET-CT: Occult metastasis. Laparoscopy: Peritoneal washings (Gastric).
mgmt:
Esophageal

Surgery: Esophagectomy (Ivor-Lewis). Adjuvant: Chemo/Radio (CROSS protocol).

Gastric

Surgery: Total or Subtotal Gastrectomy with D2 Lymphadenectomy. Adjuvant: Chemotherapy (FLOT).

Palliative

Stenting (for dysphagia), Radiotherapy.
complications:
Complications
  • Tracheoesophageal Fistula.
  • Aspiration Pneumonia.
  • Severe Malnutrition.
  • Bleeding (Hematemesis).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Barrett's Esophagus
Intestinal metaplasia (Squamous → Columnar) of distal esophagus due to chronic acid exposure. Increases Adenocarcinoma risk by 30-125x. Surveillance required.

name: Acute Appendicitis
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Did the pain start in the middle and move to the right?" (Murphy's sequence)
  • "Does it hurt when you cough or go over bumps?" (Peritonism)
  • "Are you hungry?" (Anorexia is almost universal)
  • "When was your last period?" (Rule out Ectopic/Ovarian causes)
  • "Any urinary symptoms?" (Pelvic appendix can irritate bladder)
Differential Diagnosis
  • Mesenteric Adenitis: Children, recent URI history, high fever.
  • Ectopic Pregnancy: Missed period, hypotension, positive hCG.
  • Ureteric Colic: Loin to groin pain, hematuria, no peritonism.
  • Terminal Ileitis (Crohn's/Yersinia): Diarrhea history.
  • Ovarian Cyst Pathology: Torsion or rupture, pelvic USG findings.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Classically begins as poorly localized peri-umbilical colicky pain (visceral T10). Within 6-24 hours, pain shifts to the Right Iliac Fossa (RIF) and becomes constant/sharp (somatic parietal irritation).

Associated Symptoms

Anorexia (hamburger sign), Nausea, Vomiting (usually follows pain), low-grade fever.

Aggravating Factors

Movement, coughing, deep inspiration (Dunphy's sign).
etiology:
Pathophysiology

Obstruction of the appendiceal lumen by fecalith (adults), lymphoid hyperplasia (children/viral), seeds, or worms (Enterobius). Obstruction → Bacterial overgrowth → Distension → Venous ischemia → Gangrene → Perforation.

Organisms

Mixed aerobic/anaerobic (E. coli, Bacteroides).
exam:
General

Flushed, low-grade pyrexia, fetor oris, tachycardia.

Abdomen

Tenderness at McBurney's Point (1/3 from ASIS to Umbilicus). Guarding and Rebound tenderness.

Specific Signs

Rovsing's Sign: Palpation of LIF causes pain in RIF (gas displacement).
Psoas Sign: Pain on extension of right hip (Retrocecal appendix).
Obturator Sign: Pain on internal rotation of flexed right hip (Pelvic appendix).
inv:
Bedside

Urine Dip (Exclude UTI/Pregnancy - mild hematuria/pyuria possible if appendix abuts ureter).

Labs

FBC (Neutrophilic leukocytosis), CRP (Elevated).

Imaging

USG (Children/Females): Non-compressible tubular structure >6mm, target sign. CT Abdomen (Men/Elderly): High sensitivity, fat stranding, appendicolith.
mgmt:
Medical

IV Fluids, Antibiotics (e.g., Cefuroxime + Metronidazole), Analgesia.

Surgical

Laparoscopic Appendectomy: Gold standard.

Appendiceal Mass

If a palpable mass presents (omentum wrapped around appendix), conservative management (Ochsner-Sherren regimen): Antibiotics + Interval appendectomy later. If patient deteriorates → Surgery.
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Perforation: Generalized peritonitis.
  • Appendiceal Mass/Abscess: Localized collection.
  • Pylephlebitis: Septic thrombosis of the portal vein (rare, high mortality).
Treatment Related
  • Surgical Site Infection (Common).
  • Pelvic Abscess.
  • Bowel Injury.
  • Post-op Ileus.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Alvarado Score (MANTRELS)
Migration (1), Anorexia (1), Nausea (1), Tenderness RIF (2), Rebound (1), Elevated Temp (1), Leukocytosis (2), Shift to left (1).
Score <5: Unlikely. 5-6: Observation/CT. >7: Surgery likely.
ðŸ’Ž Valentino's Syndrome
Perforated Peptic Ulcer gastric contents tracking down the right paracolic gutter to the RIF, mimicking appendicitis.

name: Intestinal Obstruction
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "When did you last pass gas or stool?" (Absolute vs Relative constipation)
  • "What color is the vomit?" (Green=Bile/Proximal, Brown/Feculent=Distal)
  • "Have you had any previous abdominal surgeries?" (Adhesions)
  • "Is the pain constant or cramping?" (Colic)
  • "Is your abdomen swollen?" (Distension)
Differential Diagnosis
  • Paralytic Ileus: Absent bowel sounds, painless distension.
  • Gastroenteritis: Diarrhea is prominent, no obstipation.
  • Pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie's): Dilation without mechanical cause.
  • Ischemic Bowel: Pain out of proportion, acidosis.
  • Constipation/Fecal Impaction: Hard stool in rectum.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Cardinal Tetrad: 1. Pain: Colicky, central (small bowel) or lower (large bowel). Continuous pain suggests strangulation. 2. Vomiting: Early/Bilious (proximal SBO), Late/Feculent (distal/LBO). 3. Distension: More marked in distal obstruction. 4. Obstipation: Failure to pass flatus/stool (Absolute constipation).
etiology:
Pathology

Mechanical blockage leads to proximal dilation → fluid sequestration → dehydration → bacterial translocation.

Causes

Small Bowel (SBO): Adhesions (60-70%), Hernias (20%), Malignancy, Crohn's, Gallstone Ileus, Intussusception.
Large Bowel (LBO): Malignancy (60%), Diverticular stricture (20%), Volvulus (Sigmoid/Cecal).
exam:
General

Dehydration (tachycardia, hypotension, dry tongue).

Abdomen

Distension (resonant to percussion). Auscultation: High-pitched "tinkling" bowel sounds (mechanical) or absent (ileus/late). Hernial Orifices: Must examine groins for incarcerated hernia. PR Exam: Empty rectum, mass, or impacted feces.
inv:
Bedside

VBG (Lactate - Ischemia).

Imaging

Abdominal X-Ray (AXR): Dilated loops. Small bowel (central, valvulae conniventes traversing width). Large bowel (peripheral, haustra partially traversing). Air-fluid levels (erect).
CT Abdomen (Contrast): Gold standard. Identifies transition point, cause (e.g., mass, hernia), and complications (ischemia/perforation).
mgmt:
Conservative ("Drip & Suck")

Aggressive IV Fluids (correct electrolyte imbalance), Nasogastric Tube (decompression/aspiration), Urinary Catheter. Gastrografin challenge for adhesive SBO (therapeutic and diagnostic).

Surgical

Indications: Strangulation (peritonitis, fever, tachycardia, leukocytosis), Virgin abdomen (no prior surgery), Irreducible hernia, Failed conservative management >48h.
Resection of non-viable bowel + anastomosis or stoma.
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Strangulation: Compromised blood supply → Gangrene → Perforation.
  • Perforation: Fecal peritonitis (high mortality).
  • Aspiration Pneumonia: From feculent vomiting.
  • Acute Kidney Injury: Due to severe dehydration/third spacing.
Treatment Related
  • Short Bowel Syndrome (if massive resection).
  • Stoma complications.
  • Anastomotic Leak.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Rule of 3-6-9
Upper limit of normal bowel diameter on AXR:
3cm Small Bowel.
6cm Large Bowel (Colon).
9cm Cecum.
ðŸ’Ž Closed Loop Obstruction
Obstruction at two points (e.g., Volvulus or competent ileocecal valve in CA Colon). Rapid progression to ischemia/perforation. Surgical emergency.

name: Colorectal Carcinoma
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Have you noticed a change in your bowel habit?" (Loose/Constipated)
  • "Is there blood in your stool or on the paper?"
  • "Do you feel like you haven't finished emptying?" (Tenesmus - rectal tumor)
  • "Have you lost weight?"
  • "Any family history of bowel cancer?"
Differential Diagnosis
  • Diverticular Disease: Altered habit, bleeding, but usually cyclic pain.
  • Inflammatory Bowel Disease: Mucus, diarrhea, younger age.
  • Hemorrhoids: Fresh red blood, no weight loss.
  • Angiodysplasia: Painless bleeding in elderly.
  • Infectious Gastroenteritis: Acute onset.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Symptoms depend on location:
Right Sided (Cecum/Ascending): Often silent. Iron deficiency anemia (occult bleed), RIF Mass, weight loss.
Left Sided (Sigmoid/Descending): Change in bowel habit (constipation/diarrhea), rectal bleeding, colicky pain, obstruction.
Rectal: Tenesmus, fresh bleeding, mucus discharge.
etiology:
Pathogenesis

Adenoma-Carcinoma Sequence: APC mutation (early) → K-RAS → p53 (late).

Risk Factors

Age, Diet (Red meat, low fiber), Obesity, Alcohol, Smoking, IBD (UC > Crohn's).

Genetics

FAP: APC gene (100% risk). Lynch Syndrome (HNPCC): DNA mismatch repair (MLH1/MSH2).
exam:
General

Pallor (Anemia), Cachexia, Supraclavicular node (Virchow's).

Abdomen

Palpable mass (Right iliac fossa or Left iliac fossa). Hepatomegaly (metastases).

Rectal Exam (DRE)

Mandatory. Assess for low rectal masses, fixation, and blood.
inv:
Labs

FBC (Microcytic Anemia), CEA (Carcinoembryonic Antigen - for monitoring, not screening).

Diagnosis

Colonoscopy + Biopsy: Gold standard.

Staging

CT Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis: Distant mets (Liver/Lung). MRI Pelvis: For rectal cancer local staging (mesorectal fascia involvement).
mgmt:
Surgical (Resection)

Goal is removal of tumor with vascular pedicle and lymphatic drainage.
Right Hemicolectomy: Cecal/Ascending tumors.
Left Hemicolectomy: Descending colon.
High Anterior Resection: Sigmoid tumors.
Low Anterior Resection (LAR): Rectal tumors (spares sphincter).
Abdominoperineal Resection (APR): Low rectal tumors involving sphincter (Permanent colostomy).

Adjuvant

Chemotherapy (FOLFOX) for Stage III (Node positive). Radiotherapy for Rectal CA.
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Large Bowel Obstruction (20% presentation).
  • Perforation (Peritonitis).
  • Fistula (Colovesical - pneumaturia).
  • Metastasis (Liver, Lung, Peritoneum).
Treatment Related
  • Anastomotic Leak.
  • Stoma complications (Retraction, Prolapse, Hernia).
  • Ureteric Injury.
  • Sexual Dysfunction (Nerve damage in rectal surgery).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Dukes' Staging
A: Confined to bowel wall (90% 5y survival).
B: Through wall, nodes negative (60%).
C: Lymph nodes positive (30%).
D: Distant metastases (<10%).
ðŸ’Ž Amsterdam Criteria (Lynch)
3-2-1 Rule: 3 relatives with CRC, 2 generations, 1 diagnosed <50 years.

name: Diverticular Disease
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Do you have pain in the left lower belly?"
  • "Have you had this pain before?" (Recurrent)
  • "Do you have a fever?"
  • "Do you have constipation?"
  • "Any blood in your stool?"
Differential Diagnosis
  • Colorectal Cancer: Indistinguishable clinically if mass present.
  • IBS: Pain relieved by defecation, no fever/inflammation.
  • Ischemic Colitis: Bloody diarrhea, CVD risk factors.
  • Ureteric Colic.
  • Gynaecological (PID, Ovarian Cyst).
history:
Definitions

Diverticulosis: Presence of diverticula. Diverticulitis: Inflammation/Infection.

History of Presenting Illness

Left Iliac Fossa (LIF) pain (Left-sided appendicitis), fever, altered bowel habit (constipation > diarrhea), nausea.

Risk Factors

Low fiber diet, Age, Obesity, NSAIDs/Steroids.
etiology:
Pathophysiology

Acquired pulsion diverticula (herniation of mucosa/submucosa) through muscularis propria at weak points where vasa recta penetrate. Caused by high intraluminal pressure (straining). Most common in Sigmoid colon.
exam:
Signs

LIF tenderness, Guarding (localized peritonitis). Palpable boggy mass (phlegmon/abscess). Tachycardia/Pyrexia.
inv:
Labs

WBC (High), CRP (High).

Imaging

CT Abdomen (Contrast): Diagnostic test of choice. Shows bowel wall thickening, pericolic fat stranding, abscess, air bubbles.
Colonoscopy: Contraindicated in acute phase (risk of perforation) but mandatory 6 weeks later to rule out cancer.
mgmt:
Uncomplicated (Hinchey I)

Oral antibiotics (Amoxiclav + Metronidazole) and liquid diet. Outpatient if mild.

Complicated

Abscess (>3-4cm): CT-guided Percutaneous Drainage.
Perforation/Peritonitis: Emergency Surgery (Hartmann's Procedure: Sigmoidectomy + End Colostomy).
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Perforation: Fecal or Purulent peritonitis.
  • Abscess: Pelvic collection.
  • Fistula: Colovesical (pneumaturia/UTIs), Colovaginal.
  • Stricture: Post-inflammatory obstruction.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Hinchey Classification
I: Pericolic abscess/inflammation.
II: Pelvic/Distant abscess.
III: Purulent peritonitis.
IV: Fecal peritonitis.

name: Lower GI Bleeding
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Is the blood bright red, dark, or mixed with stool?"
  • "Does it hurt when you pass blood?" (Anal fissure)
  • "Are you lightheaded or dizzy?"
  • "Are you on blood thinners?"
  • "Have you had previous episodes?"
Differential Diagnosis
  • Diverticulosis: Painless, large volume, arterial bleed.
  • Hemorrhoids: Fresh red blood on paper/pan, painless.
  • Angiodysplasia: Elderly, right-sided, venous ooze.
  • Colorectal Cancer.
  • Ischemic Colitis: Painful bloody diarrhea.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Hematochezia (passage of fresh blood).
Bright Red: Rectal/Anal/Left Colon.
Dark Red/Maroon: Right Colon/Small Bowel.
Painless: Diverticular, Angiodysplasia.
Painful: Ischemia, Fissure, IBD.
etiology:
Causes

Diverticular Disease (30-50%): Erosion of vasa recta at neck of diverticulum.
Angiodysplasia: Degenerative vascular dilation.
Post-Polypectomy: Ulceration of stalk.
Colitis: IBD, Infectious, Radiation.
exam:
Signs

DRE (check for anorectal pathology/blood). Hemodynamic status (Shock). Abdominal tenderness (Ischemia/Colitis).
inv:
Diagnosis

CT Angiography: First line for active massive bleed (detects >0.3ml/min).
Colonoscopy: Diagnostic and therapeutic if stable.
Red Cell Scan: For slow intermittent bleeds.
mgmt:
Resuscitation

Stabilize hemodynamics (IV Fluids/Blood). Stop anticoagulants.

Intervention

Endoscopic: Clips/Adrenaline (for post-polypectomy or angiodysplasia).
Interventional Radiology: Angio-embolization (for diverticular bleed).
Surgery: Subtotal Colectomy (if bleeding source unidentified and life-threatening).
complications:
Complications
  • Hypovolemic Shock.
  • Anemia.
  • Myocardial Infarction (Demand ischemia).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Heyde's Syndrome
Association between Aortic Stenosis and Angiodysplasia (acquired vWF deficiency). Bleeding often stops after valve replacement.

name: Renal Stones (Urolithiasis)
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Do you have severe pain from loin to groin?"
  • "Are you unable to get comfortable?" (Restless)
  • "Is there blood in your urine?"
  • "Are you vomiting?"
  • "Do you have a fever?" (Red flag for infected obstructed kidney)
Differential Diagnosis
  • Appendicitis: RIF pain.
  • Ruptured AAA: Older male, shock.
  • Pyelonephritis: Fever, rigors, tenderness.
  • Musculoskeletal Back Pain: Worse with movement, not colicky.
  • Biliary Colic: RUQ pain.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Classic Ureteric Colic: Sudden, agonizing, fluctuating pain radiating from loin to groin/scrotum/labia. Patient moves constantly (unlike peritonitis). Nausea and vomiting due to vagal stimulation.
etiology:
Pathogenesis

Supersaturation of urine → Nucleation → Crystal Growth.

Types

Calcium Oxalate (75%): Radio-opaque.
Struvite (15%): Infection (Proteus), staghorn, Radio-opaque.
Uric Acid (5%): Radio-lucent (invisible on X-ray).
Cystine: Genetic.
exam:
Signs

Renal angle tenderness. Dehydration. Afebrile (unless infected). Soft abdomen.
inv:
Labs

Urine Dip (Hematuria in 90%). U/E (Creatinine). FBC/CRP (Infection).

Imaging

CT KUB (Non-contrast): Gold standard (Sens/Spec >99%).
USG KUB: For hydronephrosis (pregnant/children).
mgmt:
Acute

NSAIDs (Diclofenac PR) - better than opioids for colic. IV Fluids. Tamsulosin (expulsive therapy for <10mm).

Definitive

<5mm: Spontaneous passage likely.
ESWL (Shockwave): Non-invasive.
URS (Ureteroscopy): Laser fragmentation.
PCNL (Percutaneous): For large renal/staghorn stones.

Emergency

Decompression (Nephrostomy or JJ Stent) if infected obstructed kidney.
complications:
Complications
  • Hydronephrosis: Back pressure damage.
  • Pyonephrosis: Pus in kidney (Sepsis source).
  • Renal Failure: If bilateral or solitary kidney.
  • Stricture: Post-stone passage.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Staghorn Calculus
Large branching stone filling the renal pelvis and calyces. Usually Struvite (Mg-NH4-PO4) caused by urease-producing bacteria (Proteus).

name: Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Do you have trouble starting your stream?" (Hesitancy)
  • "Do you wake up at night to pee?" (Nocturia)
  • "Is the stream weak or stopping and starting?"
  • "Do you feel like you haven't emptied completely?"
  • "Do you dribble at the end?"
Differential Diagnosis
  • Prostate Cancer: Hard nodule on DRE.
  • Urethral Stricture: History of trauma/STI.
  • UTI: Dysuria, frequency.
  • Neurogenic Bladder: Diabetes, Spinal cord injury.
  • Bladder Stone: Interruption of stream.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms (LUTS).
Voiding (Obstructive): Hesitancy, poor flow, intermittency, incomplete emptying.
Storage (Irritative): Frequency, urgency, nocturia.
etiology:
Pathophysiology

Hyperplasia of stromal and epithelial cells in the Transition Zone of the prostate. Driven by Dihydrotestosterone (DHT). Leads to Bladder Outflow Obstruction (BOO).
exam:
Signs

Palpable bladder (if retention).
DRE: Smooth, enlarged, distinct median sulcus, rubbery consistency.
inv:
Labs

PSA: To rule out cancer (can be elevated in BPH/UTI). U/E: Renal function.

Functional

Uroflowmetry: Qmax <10ml/s = Obstruction. Bladder Scan: Residual volume.
mgmt:
Medical

Alpha-blockers (Tamsulosin): Relax smooth muscle (Rapid relief).
5-Alpha Reductase Inhibitors (Finasteride): Shrink prostate (Takes 6 months).

Surgical

TURP (Transurethral Resection of Prostate): Gold standard.
Newer: Laser (HoLEP), UroLift, Steam (Rezum).
complications:
Complications
  • Acute Urinary Retention (AUR).
  • Chronic Retention (Overflow incontinence).
  • Bladder Stones.
  • Recurrent UTIs.
  • Post-renal Failure.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž IPSS Score
International Prostate Symptom Score.
0-7 (Mild): Watchful waiting.
8-19 (Mod): Medical.
20-35 (Severe): Surgery.

name: Prostate Cancer
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Do you have a family history of prostate cancer?"
  • "Do you have back pain?" (Bone mets)
  • "Have you seen blood in your semen or urine?"
  • "Have you lost weight?"
  • "Do you have urinary symptoms?" (Often late)
Differential Diagnosis
  • Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH).
  • Chronic Prostatitis: Pain, tenderness.
  • Prostatic Calculi.
  • Urethral Stricture.
  • Cystitis.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Often asymptomatic (raised PSA). Advanced: LUTS, Hematospermia, Bone pain (vertebral metastases), Cord compression (weak legs).

Risk Factors

Age (>65), Ethnicity (African-Caribbean), Family History (BRCA2).
etiology:
Pathology

Adenocarcinoma (95%). Arises in the Peripheral Zone (accessible to DRE).

Spread

Local invasion, Lymphatics (Obturator/Iliac), Hematogenous (Bone - sclerotic mets).
exam:
DRE

Hard, craggy/nodular, irregular prostate. Loss of median sulcus.
inv:
Labs

PSA (Prostate Specific Antigen): Age-specific thresholds. High in CA, BPH, UTI, Ejaculation.

Diagnosis

Multiparametric MRI: PI-RADS score.
Transperineal Biopsy: Guided by MRI.

Staging

Bone Scan (for mets).
mgmt:
Localized

Active Surveillance: For low risk (Gleason 6).
Radical Prostatectomy: Robotic/Open.
Radiotherapy: External Beam or Brachytherapy.

Metastatic

ADT (Androgen Deprivation Therapy): LHRH agonists (Goserelin) or Antagonists. "Chemical castration".
Chemo: Docetaxel.
complications:
Complications
  • Spinal Cord Compression: Emergency.
  • Pathological Fractures.
  • Lymphedema: Legs/Scrotum.
  • Ureteric Obstruction: Renal failure.
Treatment Related
  • Erectile Dysfunction (Nerve sparing difficult).
  • Urinary Incontinence.
  • Radiation Proctitis.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Gleason Score
Sum of two most common patterns (Grade 1-5). e.g., 3+4=7.
Group 1 (6): Good prognosis.
Group 5 (9-10): Poor prognosis.

name: Bladder Cancer
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Have you passed blood in your urine without pain?"
  • "Do you smoke?" (Main risk)
  • "Have you worked with chemicals/dyes?"
  • "Did you pass clots?"
  • "Do you have pain when urinating?"
Differential Diagnosis
  • UTI: Painful, pyuria.
  • Renal/Bladder Stone: Painful colic.
  • BPH: Bleeding from enlarged veins.
  • Trauma.
  • Glomerulonephritis: Microscopic hematuria, protein.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Painless Gross Hematuria (80%). Irritative LUTS (CIS).

Risk Factors

Smoking (50% of cases), Aromatic Amines (Rubber/Dye industry), Schistosomiasis (Squamous cell), Chronic catheterization, Cyclophosphamide.
etiology:
Pathology

Transitional Cell Carcinoma (TCC): 90%. Field change defect.
Squamous Cell Carcinoma: Schistosomiasis/Stones.
Adenocarcinoma: Urachal remnant.
exam:
Signs

Usually normal. Bimanual exam under anesthesia (EUA) assesses mass mobility.
inv:
Diagnosis

Flexible Cystoscopy: Visual inspection.
CT Urogram: Evaluates upper tracts (kidneys/ureters) and staging.
Urine Cytology: Low sensitivity, high specificity for high-grade disease.
mgmt:
Non-Muscle Invasive (NMIBC)

TURBT (Resection): Diagnostic and therapeutic.
Intravesical BCG: Immunotherapy for high risk/CIS.
Mitomycin C: Single dose post-TURBT.

Muscle Invasive (MIBC)

Radical Cystectomy: Removal of bladder + prostate/uterus + Lymph nodes. Requires urinary diversion (Ileal conduit or Neobladder).
Radiotherapy: Bladder preservation.
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Hydronephrosis (Ureteric obstruction).
  • Metastasis (Pelvic nodes, Liver, Lung, Bone).
Treatment Related
  • Stoma complications.
  • Metabolic acidosis (Ileal conduit).
  • Sexual dysfunction.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Schistosomiasis
Schistosoma haematobium infection causes chronic inflammation leading to Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the bladder. Common in Egypt/Middle East.

name: Groin Hernias
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Can you push the lump back in?" (Reducibility)
  • "Is it painful or stuck?" (Incarceration/Strangulation)
  • "Does it appear when you cough or lift heavy things?"
  • "Do you have constipation or difficulty urinating?" (Increased intra-abdominal pressure)
  • "Have you had a hernia repair before?"
Differential Diagnosis
  • Femoral Hernia: Below and lateral to pubic tubercle.
  • Inguinal Lymphadenopathy: Multiple, rubbery, or hard nodes.
  • Saphena Varix: Compressible, thrill on cough, disappears on lying.
  • Hydrocele: Scrotal swelling, transilluminates, can get above it.
  • Undescended Testis: Empty scrotum.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Lump in the groin or scrotum. Often asymptomatic. Pain or dragging sensation, especially end of day. Lump enlarges with Valsalva (cough, straining) and reduces on lying down.

Red Flags

Sudden pain, irreducible, vomiting, skin changes (Strangulation).
etiology:
Pathophysiology

Protrusion of viscus through a defect in the abdominal wall.
Indirect Inguinal: Through deep ring, lateral to inferior epigastric vessels. Patent processus vaginalis (Congenital).
Direct Inguinal: Through Hesselbach's triangle, medial to inferior epigastric vessels. Weakness of transversalis fascia (Acquired - elderly).
Femoral: Through femoral canal (below inguinal ligament). High risk of strangulation.
exam:
General

Assess for respiratory disease/ascites (causes).

Local

Inspect standing and lying. Cough Impulse: Palpable expansion. Reducibility: Ask patient to reduce. Deep Ring Occlusion Test: Reduce hernia, occlude deep ring (mid-inguinal point), ask to cough. If controlled = Indirect. If reappears = Direct (This test is unreliable). Landmark: Inguinal is Superomedial to Pubic Tubercle; Femoral is Inferolateral.
inv:
Diagnosis

Primarily Clinical.

Imaging

USG Groin: If diagnosis is uncertain or to differentiate from lymph node/hydrocele. CT Abdomen: In acute obstruction/strangulation.
mgmt:
Conservative

Watchful waiting for minimally symptomatic inguinal hernias in co-morbid patients. Truss.

Surgical

Hernioplasty (Mesh Repair):
1. Open (Lichtenstein): Tension-free mesh.
2. Laparoscopic (TEP/TAPP): Indicated for bilateral, recurrent, or active lifestyle (faster recovery).
Note: Femoral hernias always require surgery due to high strangulation risk.
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Incarceration: Irreducible but viable bowel.
  • Strangulation: Compromised blood supply -> Ischemia -> Gangrene.
  • Obstruction: Blockage of bowel loop within hernia.
Treatment Related
  • Chronic Groin Pain (Ilioinguinal nerve entrapment).
  • Ischemic Orchitis (Damage to testicular artery/veins).
  • Recurrence (<1-2% with mesh).
  • Seroma/Hematoma.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Richter's Hernia
Only the antimesenteric border of the bowel herniates and strangulates. Can occur without obstruction symptoms. Common in Femoral hernias.
ðŸ’Ž Hesselbach's Triangle
Boundaries:
Lateral: Inferior Epigastric vessels.
Medial: Rectus Abdominis.
Inferior: Inguinal Ligament.

name: Breast Cancer
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Have you noticed a lump in your breast?"
  • "Has there been any nipple discharge?" (Bloody = Suspicious)
  • "Is the nipple pulled in?" (Inversion)
  • "Any family history of breast/ovarian cancer?"
  • "When was your last period/menopause?" (Estrogen exposure)
Differential Diagnosis
  • Fibroadenoma: Mobile "breast mouse", young women.
  • Cyst: Fluid filled, fluctuating size with cycle.
  • Abscess: Lactating women, red/hot/tender.
  • Fat Necrosis: History of trauma, hard lump.
  • Fibrocystic Change: Lumpy painful breasts pre-menses.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Painless hard lump (most common). Nipple discharge (blood/stained). Nipple inversion. Skin changes (dimpling). Axillary lump. Bone pain/Breathlessness (Mets).

Risk Factors

Age, Female, Early menarche/Late menopause (High Estrogen), Nulliparity, HRT/OCP, BRCA1/2 genes, Obesity, Alcohol.
etiology:
Pathology

Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (NST): 70-80%.
Invasive Lobular Carcinoma: 10-15%. Multifocal/Bilateral.
DCIS: Pre-invasive.

Receptors

ER (Estrogen), PR (Progesterone), HER2 (Human Epidermal Growth Factor).
exam:
Signs

Hard, irregular, tethered/fixed mass. Peau d'orange (cutaneous lymphatic edema). Nipple retraction/destruction (Paget's). Palpable axillary nodes.
inv:
Triple Assessment (Gold Standard)

1. Clinical Exam.
2. Imaging: Mammogram (calcification/mass) for >35y; USG for <35y. MRI for screening high risk.
3. Pathology: Core Biopsy (Histology - preferred for receptor status) or FNAC (Cytology).
mgmt:
Surgical

WLE (Wide Local Excision): Breast conserving + Radiotherapy.
Mastectomy: If large tumor/multifocal.
Axilla: Sentinel Node Biopsy (standard) → Axillary Clearance if positive.

Adjuvant

Chemo: For high grade/node positive.
Radiotherapy: Post-WLE or Chest wall.
Endocrine: Tamoxifen (Pre-meno) or Aromatase Inhibitors (Letrozole - Post-meno) for ER+.
Targeted: Trastuzumab (Herceptin) for HER2+.
complications:
Complications
  • Lymphedema: Swelling of arm post-axillary clearance.
  • Seroma: Fluid collection in wound.
  • Winged Scapula: Long thoracic nerve injury.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Paget's Disease of Nipple
Eczema-like change of the nipple/areola. Underlying DCIS or invasive cancer in almost all cases. Biopsy mandatory.

name: Thyroid Disease
clerking:
Golden Questions
  • "Does the lump move when you swallow?"
  • "Do you prefer hot or cold weather?"
  • "Has your voice changed?" (RLN involvement - Cancer)
  • "Do you have palpitations or tremors?"
  • "Any family history of thyroid problems?"
Differential Diagnosis
  • Multinodular Goiter (MNG): Multiple lumps.
  • Graves' Disease: Diffuse goiter, eye signs.
  • Thyroglossal Cyst: Moves with tongue protrusion.
  • Thyroiditis: Painful/Tender.
  • Lymph Node: Does not move with swallow.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Lump: Goiter (diffuse/nodular).
Hyperthyroid: Weight loss, increased appetite, heat intolerance, tremor, palpitations, anxiety, diarrhea.
Hypothyroid: Weight gain, cold intolerance, lethargy, constipation, dry skin.
Compression: Dysphagia, dyspnea, stridor.
etiology:
Causes

Goiter: Iodine deficiency, Graves' (Autoimmune), Hashimoto's.
Malignancy: Papillary (80%), Follicular (10%), Medullary (MEN2 - Calcitonin), Anaplastic (Elderly, aggressive).
exam:
Signs

Thyroid Status: Pulse, Tremor, Reflexes. Eye Signs: Exophthalmos, Lid lag (Graves). Neck: Palpate from behind. Check movement with swallow. Retrosternal dullness. Pemberton's sign (facial congestion on raising arms).
inv:
Labs

TSH, T3, T4. Thyroid Antibodies (Anti-TPO, TRAb). Calcitonin (Medullary).

Imaging

USG: Solid vs Cystic, microcalcifications.

Pathology

FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration): Bethesda classification. Cannot distinguish Follicular Adenoma from Carcinoma (needs histology).
mgmt:
Medical

Thyrotoxicosis: Carbimazole/Propylthiouracil, Beta-blockers. Hypo: Levothyroxine.

Radioiodine (I-131)

For Graves' or Cancer. Avoid in pregnancy/eye disease.

Surgical

Indications: Malignancy, Compression, Cosmesis, Failed medical.
Total Thyroidectomy or Hemithyroidectomy.
complications:
Complications
  • Hypocalcemia: Parathyroid injury (tingling, tetany).
  • Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve Injury: Hoarseness (unilateral) or Airway obstruction (bilateral).
  • Hematoma: Airway compression (Emergency).
  • Thyroid Storm: Life-threatening thyrotoxicosis.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Papillary Carcinoma
Most common thyroid cancer. Spreads via lymphatics. Histology: "Orphan Annie" nuclei and Psammoma bodies. Good prognosis.
